awd_titl_txt: Atomic Coherence and Interference in a Coupled Atom-Cavity System
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports an experimental research program that studies coherent photon-atom interactions in a coupled cavity-atom system consisting of multiple multi-level atoms interacting with one or two cavity modes and also with free-space laser fields. The experiments are carried out with laser-cooled rubidium atoms confined in an optical resonator. The prior work of the PI's group showed that the collective coupling of the cavity field and atoms can be used to produce the intra-cavity dark state and create cavity electromagnetically induced transparency. The PI's group also showed that the free-space laser field can be used to induce the destructive interference in the coupled cavity-atom system and control the quantum states of the cavity QED system. The planned experiments will use such interplay of the cavity QED and the quantum interference induced by the free-space laser fields to obtain large optical nonlinearities and to study light control light phenomena such as all-optical switching and large cross-phase modulation at ultra-low light intensities. The experiments will also be carried out in the cavity-atom system with a free-space, multi-frequency control light field that creates broadband electromagnetically induced transparency, which is useful for studies of a multichannel, broadband light memory. 
  
The funded research will advance knowledge of the fundamental physics of photon-atom interactions, lead to discoveries of new phenomena, and result in the development of coherent optical techniques for applications in quantum state manipulation, spectroscopic measurements, light-control-light photonic devices, and storage and conversion of quantum information. The research activities are carried out at Florida International University (a minority institute) and involve contributions from graduate and undergraduate students, particularly minority students. The research projects use advanced experimental methods and perform sophisticated experiments with advanced laser optical techniques and spectroscopic measurements, which offers research related education and training opportunities for the graduate and undergraduate students and enable them to develop scientific knowledge and technical skills in their pursuit of scientific and technological careers.

por.por_cntn:
We have made significant progresses in the funded research program and observed several new phenomena manifested by quantum interference in cavity quantum electrodynamics (CQED). We developed optical techniques to manipulate the quantum states of the CQED system and to study nonlinear optics at low light intensities. During the award period, we published nine research papers in refereed physics journals and gave four invited presentations in the international and national conferences and meetings.

   Specifically, we devised a method to study the quantum nonlinear CQED and observed the pure three-photon excitation of the quantum ladder states of the CQED system. The experimental measurements agree with the theoretical analysis based on a fully quantized treatment of the CQED system, but disagree with the semiclassical analysis of the CQED system. Thus our experimental work represents the first observation of the multi-ladder structure of the CQED states and reveals directly the quantum nature of the multi-atom CQED system.

    We also observed that the destructive quantum interference can be induced in a CQED system and can be reversed by a control laser, which leads to the resonantly enhanced nonlinear excitation of the polariton state. Our experiment reveals intricate features of the evolution of the quantum interference from destructive to constructive via experimentally controllable parameters.

   We continue to explore new ideas and proposed a method to realize the interaction-free light-control-light in a CQED system. Such interaction-free control can be used to manipulate the linear susceptibility of the cavity-confined atoms, and to induce the large nonlinear susceptibilities, which can be used to study the two-channel large cross-phase modulation and all optical switching.

   In working with our collaborators, we developed a fully quantized theoretical method for the coherently prepared, multiatom CQED system. The method has been used to analyze the multiphoton excitation of the CQED system and confirm the experimental observation of the quantum nature of the CQED ladder states. The quantized theoretical method will enable us to study the statistical properties of the CQED system, and explore the nonclassical light generation and photon correlations in the nonlinear regime of the CQED.  We proposed a scheme to realize the perfect photon absorption in both the linear and nonlinear regimes of CQED. Our work showed that it is possible to induce and control the optical bistability by varying the phase of the input light fields. The perfect photon absorption in CQED opens possibilities for realizing the all-optical switching at single photon levels and obtaining the 0 to 180 degrees phase jump in the CQED system for the phase gate application.

  During the funding period, we continued to build the laboratory capabilities and adapted advanced experimental methods and sophisticated optoelectronics techniques for the funded research project. Our work has advanced the fundamental knowledge on the cavity enhanced photon-atom interactions and its manifestation in nonlinear optics and quantum optics, and contributed to the development of the optical techniques for studies of nonlinear optics at low light intensities and spectroscopic measurements. Our research program provided learning and training opportunities for two graduate students, two undergraduate students, three postdoc researchers, and one visiting professor.  The success of our research program has contributed to the improvement of the physics research programs at Florida International University (FIU), made positive impact to the overall development of the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education at FIU, and broadened the participation of students (including minority students) in the fundamental physics research.
